Beethoven.passage: If Beethoven (9th of February 1770 – 26th February 1827) did not actually compose music, the world would be poorer for it. Beethoven’s music, though, differed from most of these composers’ works. Beethoven, with more than three thousand compositions, was the most prolific composer of the eighteenth and early nineteenth century and his work spanned genres from the symphony and chamber works to opera and orchestral work. And although he was a leading figure of the 19th-century Romantic Era, he had the ability to be the most innovative composers in history — and for a man whose music so often had nothing to do with the Romantic Era, this is a feat to be highly commended. And, whilst Beethoven’s works have since been more and more replete with classical elements, such as the ‘Romantic’ symphony and Beethoven is also a leading classical composer in modern musical history. Offenbach.passage: “Louis-Philippe Auguste, Duke of Orléans was known as “L’Imposteur” (“the impostor”) by the nickname he had gained from his opponent, General Charles-Jean-Luc de Villeroi during the Battle of Orléans. The Duke of Orléans was also known as “Le Bateau-qui-fuit” (“the boat that escaped”) for his escape from the battle and later from his imprisonment. Louis-Philippe.passage: “When the young Louis-Philippe finally succeeded to the throne, the age of Enlightenment ideas had already reached the peak of influence in France. Napoleon had abolished the aristocracy in 1790 and Louis-Philippe’s accession marked a dramatic change of politics. The new monarch did not share any of the ideas of his Enlightenment-thinking predecessor, and instead opted for a course of action which was completely at odds with them. Louis-Philippe began his reign by reviving the royal bureaucracy of the French State. He then issued a number of decrees which were anathema to the revolutionary ideals for which Napoleon had fought. These were decrees to abolish the old feudal system, to end feudal subsidies, to introduce liberty of the press, the abolition of the French nobility and the rise of the middle class. In 1792, he issued an Edict of Nantes, which outlawed the practice of feudalism. He continued his reign with an autocratic style, but his “revolutionary” policies led to his reign being very short-lived, after he was overthrown in 1792 after he attempted to restore the old feudal system.

France.passage: France is a country located in Western Europe. It is the largest country in Europe by land area and population. It is also the most visited country in the world, with over 82 million foreign visitors in 2006. France is a member of the European Union and is one of the world's leading industrial powers. It is home to the world's most prestigious universities, including the Sorbonne, Ecole Normale Supérieure, and Sciences Po. France is also home to the world's most prestigious fashion houses, including Christian Louboutin, Louis Vuitton, and Hermès. The French are known for their love of food and wine, and the country is home to some of the world's most famous chefs, including Alain Ducasse and Joël Robuchon. France is also home to some of the world's most famous writers, including Jean-Paul Sartre and Victor Hugo. The French are also known for their love of cinema, and France is home to some of the world's most famous film festivals, including the Cannes Film Festival. The country is also home to some of the world's most famous football clubs, including Paris Saint-Germain and Marseille. The French are also known for their love of music, and France is home to some of the world's most famous musicians, including Edith Piaf and Jacques Brel.

qae_pairs.question: Question: Who is known as the 'Piaf of France' and what is her most famous song?
qae_pairs.explanation: Edith Piaf (1915-1949) was a French singer and songwriter. She is known as the Piaf of France and is considered one of the most iconic singers in the history of French music. Her most famous song is La Vie en Rose, which was written by the French composer Edith Piaf and the American songwriter George Gershwin. The song was a hit in France and has since become a classic in many other countries.

qae_pairs.question: What is the most famous fashion house in France?
qae_pairs.explanation: Hermès is a French luxury brand that designs and sells a wide range of products, including fashion, leather goods, and accessories. The brand is known for its high-quality products and its unique design, and is considered one of the worlds most prestigious fashion houses.

qae_pairs.question: Which year did France have the highest number of foreign visitors?
qae_pairs.explanation: 2006 was the year that France had the highest number of foreign visitors, with over 82 million visitors.
